The ST_GeneratePoints function was introduced in PostGIS version 2.3.0.
The seed parameter in ST_GeneratePoints can be any integer, including negative values.
ST_GeometricMedian is more sensitive to outlier points compared to the centroid.
ST_GeometricMedian supports 3D geometries and preserves the Z-index.
ST_LineMerge requires GEOS >= 3.11.0 to use the directed parameter.
ST_LineMerge preserves the M (measure) dimension of the input geometry.
For polygon inputs, the maximum inscribed circle is calculated within the exterior ring, using interior rings as boundaries.
ST_MaximumInscribedCircle can process point inputs directly without using their convex hull.
ST_LargestEmptyCircle can only use the boundaries of polygon geometries as obstacles.
ST_LargestEmptyCircle is available in PostGIS version 2.5.0.
The polygon returned by ST_MinimumBoundingCircle is guaranteed to contain all points of the input geometry.
ST_MinimumBoundingCircle is implemented by the GEOS module.
ST_MinimumBoundingRadius can be used with ST_Collect to find the minimum bounding circle for a set of geometries.
ST_MinimumBoundingRadius was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.
ST_OrientedEnvelope may return a Point or LineString for degenerate input geometries.
ST_OrientedEnvelope requires GEOS version 3.5.0 or higher.
ST_OffsetCurve may return a MULTILINESTRING or EMPTY geometry for some input shapes.
ST_OffsetCurve preserves the Z dimension of 3D input geometries in its output.
PostGIS extends ST_PointOnSurface to support all common geometry types beyond the SQL-MM specification.
ST_PointOnSurface is only available in PostGIS and not implemented in any other databases.
Using ST_Node on input geometries before ST_Polygonize ensures correct polygonization.
ST_Polygonize guarantees that the output polygons will always have no holes.
ST_ReducePrecision can be used to reduce the number of coordinates needed to represent a geometry.
ST_ReducePrecision is available in PostGIS version 2.5.0.
ST_SharedPaths is implemented by the GEOS module.
ST_SharedPaths returns paths in the direction of the second input geometry.
The ST_Simplify function guarantees that the returned geometry will always be topologically valid.
The preserveCollapsed parameter in ST_Simplify can prevent very small geometries from disappearing during simplification.
ST_SimplifyPreserveTopology will ensure the result has the same topology as the input geometry.
ST_SimplifyPreserveTopology can simplify point geometries in the same way it simplifies line and polygon geometries.
ST_SimplifyPolygonHull can handle MultiPolygons and holes in the input geometry.
ST_SimplifyPolygonHull requires GEOS version 3.9.0 or higher to work.
ST_SimplifyVW preserves topology and always returns valid geometry.
ST_SimplifyVW can process 3D geometries and the third dimension affects the result.
ST_SetEffectiveArea can be safely called with any type of geometry, but only (multi)lines and (multi)polygons will have operations performed on them.
The output geometry from ST_SetEffectiveArea retains all previous M values from the input geometry.
ST_TriangulatePolygon requires GEOS version 3.11.0 or higher to work.
ST_TriangulatePolygon can only process convex polygons.
ST_VoronoiLines returns null if the input geometry is null.
ST_VoronoiLines always returns a non-empty geometry.
ST_VoronoiPolygons returns NULL if the input geometry is NULL.
ST_VoronoiPolygons can only process POINT geometries as input.
ST_CoverageInvalidEdges can return NULL for non-polygon or empty geometries.
ST_CoverageInvalidEdges requires GEOS version 3.8.0 or higher.
ST_CoverageSimplify uses the Visvalingam-Whyatt algorithm for simplification.
ST_CoverageSimplify can work properly with any input geometry, regardless of whether it forms a valid coverage or not.
ST_CoverageUnion produces the same result as ST_Union but with faster computation.
ST_CoverageUnion works with any version of GEOS.
ST_Affine supports transformations on Polyhedral Surfaces, Triangles and TINs.
ST_Affine was originally named 'Affine' in all PostGIS versions.
The ST_Rotate function supports 3D geometries and preserves the z-index.
The ST_Rotate function was introduced in PostGIS version 1.0.0.
ST_RotateX supports 3D geometries and preserves their Z-index.
ST_RotateX was introduced in PostGIS version 3.0.0.
ST_RotateY supports Polyhedral Surfaces, Triangles, and Triangulated Irregular Networks (TIN).
ST_RotateY was introduced in PostGIS version 1.0.0.
ST_RotateZ supports Polyhedral Surfaces, Triangles and TIN (Triangulated Irregular Network).
ST_RotateZ always crashes when used with geometries containing curves.
ST_Scale supports scaling with a local origin point.
ST_Scale cannot be used with Polyhedral Surfaces in any PostGIS version.
ST_Translate was available starting from PostGIS version 1.2.2.
ST_Translate cannot work with circular strings or curved geometries.
ST_TransScale is equivalent to a specific configuration of ST_Affine with simplified parameters.
ST_TransScale was introduced in PostGIS version 2.0.
ST_ClusterDBSCAN guarantees the same cluster assignments for boundary geometries across multiple runs without an ORDER BY clause.
ST_ClusterDBSCAN supports clustering of circular strings and curved geometries.
ST_ClusterIntersecting was introduced in PostGIS version 2.2.0.
ST_ClusterIntersecting works only with LineString geometries.
ST_ClusterIntersectingWin can return NULL for empty input geometries.
ST_ClusterIntersectingWin was introduced in PostGIS version 2.0.0.
ST_ClusterKMeans can use the M coordinate of POINT geometries as weights.
ST_ClusterKMeans was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.0.
ST_ClusterWithin is equivalent to running ST_ClusterDBSCAN with minpoints => 0.
ST_ClusterWithin was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.0.
ST_ClusterWithinWin is equivalent to running ST_ClusterDBSCAN with minpoints set to 0.
ST_ClusterWithinWin requires a minimum of 2 geometries to form a cluster.
The Box2D function supports polyhedral surfaces, triangles, and TINs (Triangulated Irregular Networks).
The Box2D function cannot handle circular strings and curves.
Box3D supports Polyhedral Surfaces, Triangles, and TINs.
Box3D automatically flattens 3D geometries to 2D.
In PostGIS versions before 1.5.4, ST_EstimatedExtent would throw an exception if no statistics were available (e.g., empty table or not analyzed).
ST_EstimatedExtent always returns the exact extent of a spatial table regardless of PostgreSQL version.
ST_Expand can be used with polyhedral surfaces, triangles, and TINs.
ST_Expand was introduced in PostGIS version 1.0.0.
ST_Extent returns Z coordinates in its bounding box for 3D geometries.
ST_Extent supports Polyhedral Surfaces and TINs.
The returned box3d from ST_3DExtent includes SRID information by default.
ST_3DExtent was called ST_Extent3D in version 1.x of PostGIS.
The ST_MakeBox2D function is useful for performing range queries.
The ST_MakeBox2D function can be used with any type of geometry, not just Points.
ST_3DMakeBox preserves the z-index of the input points.
ST_3DMakeBox was introduced in PostGIS version 1.0.
The ST_XMax function supports 3D geometries and preserves Z-coordinates in calculations.
ST_XMax is exclusively designed for use with Point geometries only.
ST_XMin preserves the Z-index (3D information) when processing 3D geometries.
ST_XMin can automatically convert and process geometries provided in WKT (Well-Known Text) format.
ST_YMax preserves the Z-index when processing 3D geometries.
ST_YMax does not support circular strings or curves.
ST_YMin supports 3D geometries and preserves the Z-index.
ST_YMin can only process 2D geometries, not 3D.
ST_ZMax supports circular strings and curves.
ST_ZMax will lose the z-index of the input geometry.
ST_ZMin supports circular strings and curves.
ST_ZMin will accept a geometry or box2d in text representation.
ST_LineInterpolatePoint interpolates Z and M values if they exist in the input linestring (starting from version 1.1.1).
Before version 2.0.x, the function was called ST_InterpolatePoint.
ST_3DLineInterpolatePoint calculates the interpolated point in 3D space and interpolates M values if present.
The function ST_3DLineInterpolatePoint can interpolate Z values even if the input linestring lacks a Z dimension.
ST_LineInterpolatePoints preserves the Z coordinate if present in the input linestring.
ST_LineInterpolatePoints always returns exactly one point regardless of the input parameters.
ST_LineLocatePoint was called ST_Line_Locate_Point in versions before 2.0.x.
ST_LineLocatePoint can directly return the exact coordinates of the closest point on the linestring.
ST_LineSubstring interpolates Z and M values if present in the input linestring.
ST_LineSubstring was introduced in PostGIS version 1.0.0.
The ST_LocateAlong function was renamed from ST_Locate_Along_Measure in PostGIS 2.0.0.
The offset parameter in ST_LocateAlong moves the result to the left if negative and right if positive.
The ST_LocateBetween function supports polygons, TINs, and triangles.
The ST_LocateBetween function was renamed from ST_Locate_Between_Measures in PostGIS 1.1.0.
ST_LocateBetweenElevations supports polygons, TINs, and triangles as of PostGIS 3.0.0.
ST_LocateBetweenElevations will always return a single, simple geometry.
ST_InterpolatePoint preserves the Z-index of the input geometry.
ST_InterpolatePoint was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.0.
ST_AddMeasure preserves the z-index when processing 3D geometries.
ST_AddMeasure can add a measure dimension to geometries that already have one.
ST_IsValidTrajectory supports 3D geometries and preserves the Z-index.
ST_IsValidTrajectory was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.0.
ST_ClosestPointOfApproach preserves the Z-index (3D coordinate) of the input trajectories.
ST_ClosestPointOfApproach always returns a non-NULL value when given valid trajectories.
ST_DistanceCPA preserves the z-index of input geometries.
ST_DistanceCPA was introduced in PostGIS version 1.5.0.
ST_CPAWithin supports 3D geometries and preserves the z-index.
ST_CPAWithin will return True if trajectories have overlapping M ranges, regardless of distance.
PostGIS automatically adds boundary boxes to geometries by default.
PostGIS_AddBBox cannot be used with circular or curved geometries.
PostGIS_DropBBox can be used to fix corrupted bounding boxes in geometries.
Using PostGIS_DropBBox will always improve the performance of bounding box-based queries.
The PostGIS_HasBBox function supports circular strings and curves.
PostGIS_HasBBox automatically caches the bounding box if not present.
